metadata.titleEn: A database of radiogenic Sr-Nd isotopes at the "three poles”
metadata.description: The radiogenic isotope composition of strontium (Sr) and neodymium (Nd) on surface of the Earth are a powerful tool for tracing dust sources and sinks on surface of the Earth. To differentiate the spatial variability of aeolian dust sources in key cryospheric regions at the three poles (including the ‘Third Pole’ covering the high mountain area in Asia, the Arctic and Antarctica). A dataset of the Sr-Nd isotopic compositions from the terrestrial extremely cold or arid environments in this study was compiled as the similar method by Blanchet (2019). The database identified on snow, ice, sand, soil (loess) and sediment from the modern dust samples and paleoclimatic records of the three poles based on 43 different references with 967 data points in total. There are 274 data points from the third pole, 302 data points from the Arctic, and 391 data points from Antarctica. The sampling and measurement methods, and quality of these data are recognized and introduced. In each pole, geographical coordinates and other information are provided. The main scientific purpose of this dataset is to provide our own measurement and collect documentation of the Sr-Nd dataset, which will be useful for determining the sources and transport pathways of dust at the three poles and to investigate whether there are multiple dust sources for each of the poles. These datasets provide detail exhaustive documentation of the isotopic signature from the three poles at specific time intervals, which would be useful for understanding the dust source or sink of the three poles.
metadata.instructions: The data is obtained in different areas of the three poles and entered in Excel. The data is taken as library name+location+test variable+compilation, and opened in Excel.

background: The role of mineral dust in the Earth system extends well beyond its impact on the energy balance and involves interactions with the carbon cycle and glacier melting on global scales. The isotopic compositions of the radiogenic elements strontium (Sr) and neodymium (Nd) are powerful tools for tracing dust sources and sinks because their characteristics vary significantly on the surface of the Earth (including snow, sand, sediment, loess, and eolian deposits). Therefore, the combination of different isotopic signatures, specifically 87Sr/86Sr and 143Nd/144Nd (expressed as εNd(0)), has proven to be useful in discriminating among different dust source areas in Earth science. The transport of eolian dust from natural desert regions has also been identified in modern snow and ice records at the so-called “third pole” based on Sr–Nd data. However, it is still a controversial issue; for example, recent results have emphasized that eolian dust from local sources contributes significantly to high-mountain glaciers. Additionally, eolian dust from various source regions, including the Saharan Desert in North Africa and the Gobi and Taklimakan deserts in Asia, can be transported to the GrIS, and great uncertainties still exist. The Sr–Nd data from snow layers in the Berkner Island ice sheet in western Antarctica, for most of the year, support scenarios that involve contributions from proximal sources. The Sr–Nd data from insoluble dust in snow samples from East Antarctica indicate that long-distance natural dust primarily originates from Australia and that local dust originates from ice-free areas. The Sr–Nd data from Holocene ice cores from East Antarctica indicate a well-mixed atmospheric background involving a mixture of two or more sources in the Southern Hemisphere. The amount of isotopic information is currently adequate for Patagonian and non-Patagonian mineral dust exported from southern South America (SSA) and the East Antarctic ice sheet (EAIS). However, Sr–Nd data are unevenly distributed across the entire AIS. Measuring the Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica is a major challenge. Although considerable Sr–Nd data have been measured, the variations in the characteristics and measurement methods of these data make it necessary to reassess these data on the dust sources in these remote regions.
research objective: The main scientific purpose of this dataset is to provide a Sr–Nd dataset based on collective documentation and our own measurements, which will be useful for determining the sources and transport pathways of dust in snow, ice, rivers, and oceans at or near the three poles as well as to investigate whether multiple dust sources are present at each of the poles. The objective of this work was to produce a compilation of published and unpublished data from the three poles, and the specific time intervals of Sr–Nd data were limited to the Quaternary period.
challenges: The transport of dust from the low midlatitudes, which contain major deserts that are dust sources, to the Arctic region or Antarctic ice sheet (AIS) is sensitive to amplified high-latitude climatic variability. However, it is still a controversial issue; for example, recent results have emphasized that eolian dust from local sources contributes significantly to high-mountain glaciers. Additionally, eolian dust from various source regions, including the Saharan Desert in North Africa and the Gobi and Taklimakan deserts in Asia, can be transported to the GrIS, and great uncertainties still exist. Measuring the Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica is a major challenge. The answers to various questions have been hindered by a paucity of Sr–Nd data, which provide information on potential local and distal dust sources.
methods: For these reasons, we measured Sr–Nd data in some samples and collected Sr–Nd data from the literature for the three poles.
dataset: The database includes Holocene and Quaternary snow, ice, sand, soil (loess), sediment, and rock samples from the three poles based on 90 different references and our own measurement data, with a total of 1989 data points, comprising 206 data points with different grain sizes and 212 data points with fraction measurements. There are 485 data points from the third pole, 727 data points from the Arctic, and 777 data points from Antarctica.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in tracing dust sources and sinks in Earth science?
Definition.Answer: The isotopic compositions of the radiogenic elements strontium (Sr) and neodymium (Nd) are powerful tools for tracing dust sources and sinks because their characteristics vary significantly on the surface of the Earth, including snow, sand, sediment, loess, and eolian deposits.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with measuring Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from remote regions?
Definition.Answer: Measuring the Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from remote regions like Antarctica is a major challenge due to the variations in the characteristics and measurement methods of these data, and the paucity of Sr–Nd data which provide information on potential local and distal dust sources.

Definition.Question: What does the compilation of Sr–Nd data from the three poles aim to achieve in terms of understanding dust transport pathways?
Definition.Answer: The compilation of Sr–Nd data aims to determine the sources and transport pathways of dust in snow, ice, rivers, and oceans at or near the three poles and investigate whether multiple dust sources are present at each of the poles.

Comparison.Question: How do the methods of measuring Sr-Nd isotopic data in snow and ice samples compare between the different poles, in terms of challenges faced and data reliability?
Comparison.Answer: Measuring the Sr-Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica is a major challenge due to the variations in characteristics and measurement methods. The challenges include amplified climatic variability and the contribution of local dust sources to high-mountain glaciers. The reliability of data also varies with the uneven distribution of Sr-Nd data across the Antarctic ice sheet compared to more comprehensive data from other poles.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the compilation of Sr-Nd data from published and unpublished sources contribute to understanding dust transport and sources at the three poles compared to solely using newly measured data?
Comparison.Answer: The compilation of Sr-Nd data from both published and unpublished sources provides a more comprehensive dataset that covers a wider range of samples and time intervals, enhancing the understanding of dust transport and sources at the three poles. This approach allows for a broader comparison and reassessment of existing data, addressing the uneven distribution and varied characteristics of Sr-Nd data across different regions, compared to relying solely on newly measured data which might be limited in scope and coverage.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges of measuring Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in polar ice cores, and how might these challenges affect the interpretation of dust sources in these regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Measuring Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica is a major challenge due to the variations in data characteristics and measurement methods. These challenges can affect the interpretation of dust sources because they may lead to uncertainties in identifying local and distal sources of eolian dust, significantly contributing to high-mountain glaciers and complicating the understanding of transport pathways.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of Sr–Nd isotopic data from diverse sources like snow, ice, and sediments at the three poles influence the understanding of dust transport pathways?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of Sr–Nd isotopic data from diverse sources like snow, ice, and sediments can provide a comprehensive view of dust transport pathways by highlighting the different isotopic signatures and their distribution across the poles. This approach allows researchers to trace dust transport from both local and distant sources, enhancing the understanding of dust origins and atmospheric circulation patterns.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in measuring Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in measuring Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica arise from the variations in characteristics and measurement methods of the data, as well as the scarcity of Sr–Nd data, which provide information on potential local and distal dust sources.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need to reassess Sr–Nd data on dust sourcing in remote regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need to reassess Sr–Nd data on dust sourcing in remote regions is due to the considerable variations in characteristics and measurement methods of these data, making it necessary to revisit these data for understanding dust sources in these areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the reasons for the uneven distribution of Sr–Nd data across the Antarctic ice sheet?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The uneven distribution of Sr–Nd data across the Antarctic ice sheet may be attributed to the major challenge of measuring isotopic compositions in ice cores and the limited availability of data providing information on local and distal dust sources.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of integrating Sr-Nd isotopic data from various global desert regions into studies of polar snow and ice samples?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating Sr-Nd isotopic data from various global desert regions into studies of polar snow and ice samples allows researchers to trace the sources and transport pathways of dust in these regions. It helps in understanding whether multiple dust sources are present at each of the poles, which is crucial for studying the impact of dust on the Earth's climate system and geochemical processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to compile a Sr–Nd dataset based on collective documentation and measurements for the three poles?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main scientific purpose of a Sr–Nd dataset is to determine the sources and transport pathways of dust in snow, ice, rivers, and oceans at or near the three poles, and to investigate whether multiple dust sources are present at each of the poles.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives drive the collection of Sr–Nd data from literature and new measurements for the three poles?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective of collecting Sr–Nd data from literature and new measurements is to address the challenge of understanding the transport of dust from major desert regions to the Arctic and Antarctic regions, and to provide information on potential local and distal dust sources.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers integrate data from literature with their own measurements to create a comprehensive Sr–Nd isotopic dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers can integrate data by compiling published and unpublished Sr–Nd isotopic data from various sources, focusing on the Holocene and Quaternary periods. This involves collecting data from 90 different references, along with their own measurements, to ensure a wide coverage of samples from snow, ice, sand, soil, loess, sediment, and rock from the three poles.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are faced in collecting and measuring Sr–Nd isotopic data from Antarctic ice cores, and how can these be addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One major challenge is the sensitivity of dust transport to climatic variability, which affects the interpretation of Sr–Nd isotopic data. Additionally, measuring isotopic compositions in ice cores is technically demanding. Addressing these challenges requires improving data collection techniques, ensuring consistent measurement methods, and expanding the Sr–Nd dataset to cover more regions and time intervals, thereby providing a clearer understanding of local and distal dust sources.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the integration of both self-measured and literature-based Sr-Nd isotopic data to form a comprehensive dataset for polar regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of both self-measured and literature-based Sr-Nd isotopic data is enabled by a combination of direct measurements using techniques like thermal ionization mass spectrometry and the collection of data from existing literature. This approach allows for the creation of a comprehensive dataset covering various sample types, such as snow, ice, sand, soil, loess, sediment, and rock across the three poles.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are expected when measuring Sr-Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from remote regions like Antarctica, and what factors might contribute to these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Measuring the Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica is a major challenge due to the variations in characteristics and measurement methods, and the uneven distribution of Sr–Nd data across the entire Antarctic Ice Sheet (AIS). Additionally, the transport of dust from various source regions to these remote areas involves great uncertainties.

Expectation.Question: Why might the distribution of Sr-Nd data be uneven across different polar regions, and what are the potential implications for understanding dust sources and transport pathways?
Expectation.Answer: The distribution of Sr–Nd data is uneven across polar regions like the Antarctic Ice Sheet (AIS) due to the challenges in measuring these isotopic compositions and the complexities involved in tracing dust sources and sinks. This uneven distribution can hinder the comprehensive understanding of dust sources and transport pathways in these regions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges associated with collecting Sr–Nd isotopic data from snow and ice samples, especially in remote and harsh environments like the poles?
Judgmental.Answer: Collecting Sr–Nd isotopic data from snow and ice samples in remote and harsh environments such as the poles is challenging due to amplified high-latitude climatic variability and the difficulty in obtaining consistent data across different regions. There is also the challenge of distinguishing between local and distal dust sources, which adds complexity to data collection efforts.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, what are the potential benefits and drawbacks of integrating published and unpublished Sr–Nd data from diverse sources to create a comprehensive dataset for studying dust transport pathways?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating published and unpublished Sr–Nd data from diverse sources can enhance the comprehensiveness and utility of a dataset by providing a broader temporal and spatial coverage, which is beneficial for studying dust transport pathways. However, potential drawbacks include variability in data quality and measurement methods, which may necessitate reassessment to ensure consistency and reliability in interpreting dust sources and transport pathways.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how the radiogenic isotopic compositions of strontium and neodymium are measured and utilized to trace dust sources.
Assertion.Answer: The isotopic compositions of strontium (Sr) and neodymium (Nd) are measured using methods such as thermal ionization mass spectrometry. These isotopic signatures, specifically 87Sr/86Sr and 143Nd/144Nd (expressed as εNd(0)), are used to trace and discriminate among different dust source areas due to the significant variation in their characteristics across the Earth's surface.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges associated with measuring Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica.
Assertion.Answer: Measuring Sr–Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica presents challenges due to the variations in the characteristics and measurement methods of the data. There is also a paucity of Sr–Nd data, which hinders understanding of potential local and distal dust sources, making it necessary to reassess existing data to provide accurate information on dust sources.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how different isotopic signatures can help identify multiple dust sources at the three poles.
Assertion.Answer: Different isotopic signatures, such as 87Sr/86Sr and εNd(0), are useful in identifying multiple dust sources because they vary significantly on the Earth's surface and can therefore trace the movement and origin of dust particles. This tracing is crucial for understanding the sources and transport pathways of dust in snow, ice, and other samples from the three poles.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze and summarize the data collection techniques used for obtaining Sr-Nd isotopic compositions from snow, ice, and sediment samples across the three poles.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques for obtaining Sr-Nd isotopic compositions involve both direct measurements using thermal ionization mass spectrometry and the compilation of data from existing literature. Samples are collected from snow, ice, sand, soil (loess), sediment, and rock across the three poles. The data collection is focused on ensuring consistency in the calculation methods and reaching the minimum quality standards required for scientific analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges associated with measuring Sr-Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica and suggest potential solutions.
Request/Directive.Answer: One of the main challenges in measuring Sr-Nd isotopic compositions in ice cores from Antarctica is the uneven distribution of data and the variations in data characteristics and measurement methods. A potential solution is to conduct more comprehensive and standardized measurements across different locations in Antarctica to reduce uncertainties and improve data comparability. Additionally, overcoming logistical challenges in sample collection and improving collaboration among research groups could help address these issues.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential data sources or strategies for expanding the existing Sr-Nd isotopic dataset to include more comprehensive coverage of dust transport pathways in the Arctic region.
Request/Directive.Answer: To expand the existing Sr-Nd isotopic dataset, one could focus on increasing the collection of samples from underrepresented areas in the Arctic, particularly those affected by high-latitude climatic variability. Collaborating with other researchers to share unpublished data and conducting new field studies in key regions, such as around major deserts that are significant dust sources, could also enhance dataset coverage. Additionally, improving the integration of data from different time periods, including the Holocene and Quaternary, will provide a more comprehensive understanding of dust transport pathways.
